#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Microchip Your Dog
#Text=Microchipping is a technology used to locate your dog if she ever gets lost or is stolen .
#Text=Collars and tags can be helpful when you need to find a missing dog , but there 's always the chance that they could fall off .
#Text=Microchips , on the other hand , are placed just under your dog 's skin , so they 're a more reliable and permanent form of ID .
#Text=If your dog 's collar comes off , a microchip is the perfect backup option , ensuring that you and your dog will be reunited much sooner .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Getting the Microchip
#Text=Bathe your dog .
#Text=Before you get your dog microchipped , she needs to be clean .
#Text=This is so the injection site is nice and clean when the vet injects the microchip into your dog .
#Text=Refrain from microchipping your dog yourself .
#Text=You should not inject your dog with a microchip at home .
#Text=It is illegal in many states to implant your dog yourself and you can have legal action brought against you .
#Text=Even if you are able to buy a microchip from a third part source , do not implant the chip yourself .
#Text=Take your dog to the vet .
#Text=Microchips should always be injected by a qualified medical professional .

#Text=It is much safer for your dog because your vet knows exactly where the microchip should be placed , how much pressure should be used , and what to look for in the rare chance there is any reaction to the microchip .
#Text=You can hurt your dog if she is n't injected in the right way .
#Text=Fill out the paperwork .
#Text=When you are having your dog microchipped , you need to fill out the paperwork that comes with the microchip so the microchip is registered .
#Text=The information that you list on these forms is how your dog will be returned to you if she is ever lost or recovered .
#Text=Your vet will then send off the paperwork to the manufacturer 's database for you .
#Text=There is a fee to register the paperwork , which is often included in your vet bill .
#Text=Make a copy of this paperwork if your vet does n't offer you one .
#Text=This will ensure that you have all the right information about your dog 's microchip .
#Text=Check the microchip 's ID number .
#Text=Before your vet injects the microchip , she will place the microchip reader over the needle with the microchip in it to make sure it reads clearly and emits the right unique ID number .
#Text=The number should match that on your paperwork .
#Text=You should also keep this number for your records .
#Text=Have the nurse hold your dog still .
#Text=Your vet can perform the microchip injection in the normal exam room .
#Text=She will require the assistance of a nurse to help her with the injection .
#Text=The nurse will gently hold your dog steady by placing one arm beneath your dog 's body and gently place the crook of his arm under her neck .
#Text=He will then hold the dog close to his body so she ca n't move .
#Text=Have the vet inject the microchip .
#Text=Once the nurse has your dog secure , your vet can locate the place between your dog 's shoulder blades where the chip will be implanted .
#Text=You vet will gently pull up the skin in this area and she will implant the microchip , about the size of a grain of rice , directly under the skin with the applicator .
#Text=The skin does n't need an alcohol swab or other preparation as long as your dog is clean .
#Text=Recheck the microchip .
#Text=Once the microchip is implanted in your dog , the vet will recheck the chip to make sure it is still transmitting now that it is in your dog 's skin .
#Text=Once the number reads the right unique ID , your dog is ready to go .
#Text=Your vet will also routinely check the chip once a year to make sure it is functioning properly .
#Text=Keep your information up to date .
#Text=If you move , change your phone number , or if any other contact information changes , make sure you tell your vet or contact the manufacturer 's database about your change in information .
#Text=They will update your information as soon as possible so your dog can be returned to the right place if she goes missing .
#Text=Considering a Microchip
#Text=Learn why you should microchip .
#Text=Microchips greatly increase your chances of having your dog returned to you if she is lost .
#Text=Collars and other identifying tags can fall off , but microchips never leave your dog once they are implanted .
#Text=Understand how a microchip works .
#Text=A microchip is a device that emits radio waves at a certain frequency .
#Text=There are typically three different frequencies that a chip may emit at , but there are universal readers that will read all three frequencies .
#Text=When the frequency is read , the reader will display the unique ID number attached to your paperwork as well as the manufacturer of the chip .
#Text=This will tell them which database to contact in order to find your information .
#Text=The chip itself does not contain your contact information .
#Text=It just has your unique ID , which is used to access your paperwork .
#Text=Know how long microchips last .
#Text=Microchips do not run on power .
#Text=They simply reflect a signal back to the scanner .
#Text=Once your dog has been implanted with a microchip , it will last for her whole life .
#Text=Learn how much microchips cost .
#Text=Most vets charge between $ 25 to $ 50 for the implantation of a microchip .
#Text=This will vary depending on your vet .
#Text=Be aware that it does n't affect your dog 's health .
#Text=Microchipping has a very minimal chance of any side effects .
#Text=There is only a small pain felt when the microchip is injected , similar to that of any shot .
#Text=Your dog may react to this a little bit , but it will only sting for a few moments .
#Text=If your dog is smaller , there may be a little more pain at the moment of injection because she is has less padding .
#Text=No surgery or anesthesia is required to implant the microchip .
#Text=However , many owners opt to have the microchip implanted at the same time she is spayed ( or neutered if male ) so she gets both procedures handled at one time .
#Text=There have been a few documented cases of extreme side effects , such as microchip migration that leads to abscesses or , in one case , death , but these are very rare .
#Text=Quick Summary
